Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 44364 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2010 
 
 
Building Capacity for Environmental Prosecution, 
Adjudication, Dispute Resolution, Compliance, and 
Enforcement in Asia
 
(Cofinanced by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund 
under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AECEN  –  Asian Environmental Compliance and Enforcement Network 
  AJNE  –  Asian Judges’ Network on the Environment 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  IUCN         International Union for Conservation of Nature 
  MOE-I   –  Ministry of Environment of Indonesia 
  SAARC  –  South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
  TA    Technical Assistance 
  UNEP  –  United Nations Environment Programme 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention – Promoting the non-income Millennium 
Development Goals (TI – M) 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (public administration, law and judiciary) 
Theme (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (environmental policy and legislation, 
institutional development); capacity development (client relations, 
network, partnership development) 
Location impact  –  Regional (high), national (high) 
Partnership  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  B. Lohani, Finance and Administration 
General Counsel  J. Hovland, Office of the General Counsel (OGC) 
Deputy General Counsel  P. Daltrop, OGC 
   
Team leader  I. Ahsan, Counsel, OGC 
Team member  K. Mulqueeny, Senior Counsel, OGC 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The extent of environmental change in Asia over the past 20 years has been dramatic 
and presents enormous challenges.  Many environmental issues are not sufficiently covered by 
policy and regulatory frameworks. If they have been adopted as laws, they often have not been 
translated into national, provincial, and local implementing rules and regulations. Even where 
Asian countries have adequate policy, legal, and regulatory frameworks, still more work is 
required to ensure effective implementation, enforcement, and compliance.   
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognizes these challenges in its Strategy 2020.1 
The strategy calls for ADB to strengthen environmental regulatory frameworks and enforcement 
capacities of public institutions. It recognizes good governance and capacity development as 
drivers  of  change  to  improve  regional  public  goods such  as  environmental  quality.  It  also 
promotes regional cooperation. Moreover, in June 2009, ADB adopted a new Safeguard Policy 
Statement  that  prioritizes  stronger  country  environmental  safeguard  systems  by  boosting 
regulation and enforcement.      
 
3.  To help support these strategic priorities, in December 2009 ADB approved small-scale 
technical assistance (TA)2 under which, in July 2010, it and UNEP held the Asian Judges’ 
Symposium on Environmental Decision Making, the Rule of Law, and Environmental Justice 
(2010  Symposium).  The  symposium  gathered  about  120  chief  justices,  senior  judges  and 
ministry of environment officials to consider how to bolster judicial capacity for environmental 
enforcement. Participants proposed the Asian Judges Network on the Environment (AJNE) to 
improve the quality of court rulings on environmental and natural resource cases, and achieve 
effective enforcement of environmental law in the region, supported by two subregional groups 
namely the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the South Asian Association 
for Regional Cooperation (SAARC). During the 2010 Symposium, the chief justice of Pakistan, 
through his representatives, offered to host, in 2011, a regional roundtable for SAARC chief 
justices to gather momentum for environmental enforcement, and the chief justice of Indonesia 
made  a  similar  offer  for  ASEAN  countries.  This  TA  supports  Strategy  2020’s  priorities  of 
environment, regional cooperation, through governance improvements, to drive strengthened 
environmental systems3. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The chief justices and senior judiciary have a direct and indirect influence on the legal 
system  and  environmental  enforcement:  they  shape  normative  interpretations  of  legal  and 
regulatory frameworks, they issue rules and directions that affect lower courts’ priorities, and 
they play a role in judicial education. Such influence affects not only the courts but also the 
overall perceptions of the rule of law in the country and, hence, influences private sector 
investment in related sectors.  
 
5.  Effective judicial participation in ensuring environmental justice and the rule of law also 
depends on other stakeholders doing their part in promoting environmental governance. Thus, 
strengthening judicial capacity also requires supporting various stakeholders responsible for 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008—2020. 
Manila. 
2  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Strengthening of Judicial Capacity to Adjudicate Upon Environmental Laws 
and Regulations. Manila (TA 7474-REG). 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 September 2010.

2  
environmental  governance.  Equally,  in  ensuring  environmental  justice,  there  is  a  need  to 
encourage the demand side by shoring up civil society, which plays an important role in making 
justice accessible to the poor through its work in legal rights awareness.  
 
6.  Judges and prosecutors participating in the 2010 Symposium agreed on several key 
messages, including that (i) ensuring effective compliance and enforcement of environmental 
law  requires  the  entire  environmental  compliance  and  enforcement  chain  to  be  effective, 
(ii) judges play a unique role, (iii) and expanding access to environmental justice involves both 
the formal justice system and informal ways to resolve disputes. This TA seeks to respond to 
the key messages from the 2010 Symposium, and the ongoing work under the 2009 TA.  
 
7.  Global  and  regional  developments. In 2002, UNEP convened the Global Judges 
Symposium, at which participants committed to the Johannesburg Principles on the Role of Law 
and Sustainable Development (the principles). The principles committed judges to contribute to 
the realization of sustainable development by using their judicial mandate to implement, develop, 
and enforce the law, and to uphold the rule of law and democratic processes. Judges also 
agreed  that  judicial  education  and  training  on  environmental  law  through  regional  and 
subregional initiatives is urgently needed, and that judges need to collaborate within and across 
regions  to  improve  enforcement,  compliance  and  implementation  of  environmental  law. 
Importantly, the principles view not just the judicial role as critical, but the whole chain of 
environmental enforcement and other environmental legal actors.  
 
8.  Building  upon  these  developments,  in  2002  and  again  in  2003,  ADB  published  a 
compilation of training materials that had been used for a series of “train the trainers” workshops 
for academics and members of the legal profession in the region. In 2004, ADB funded a 
Judges’ Forum on Environmental Protection in the Philippines, and in August 2005, ADB and 
the United States Agency for International Development launched the Asian Environmental 
Compliance  and  Enforcement  Network  (AECEN)—a  regional  network  of  environment 
ministries—to begin promoting better enforcement of and compliance with environmental law in 
Asia and the Pacific.   
 
9.  National developments. Several Southeast Asian countries have taken various formal 
steps to strengthen and institutionalize environmental decision making within the judiciary and 
legal profession. In the Philippines, in 2008, the chief justice designated 117 environmental 
courts,  and  in  2010,  the  Supreme  Court  adopted  environmental  rules  to  make  access  to 
environmental justice easier. In Thailand, in 2009, the president of the Supreme Court issued a 
court resolution establishing a judicial committee to prepare a draft law on better environmental 
adjudication. 
 
10.  Since 1998, Indonesia has trained 20% of its judiciary in environmental law. The Ministry 
of Environment (MOE-I) has also signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the 
Supreme  Court  to  establish  a  program  to  certify  judges  as  “environmental  judges”  upon 
completion of  a  series  of  trainings.  ADB,  under  the  2009  TA,  has  been  working  with  the 
Supreme Court and MOE-I to prepare the basis for the certification scheme, but it is envisaged 
that further work will be needed to ensure its implementation. Moreover, MOE-I, the attorney 
general and the national police chief of Indonesia have entered into a separate MOU to widen 
access  to environmental  justice. The  purpose  of  this  MOU  is  to  strengthen  environmental 
governance in Indonesia and improve access to environmental justice by strengthening the 
capacity and integrity of prosecutors and adjudicators. The challenge in these countries, and 
others in Southeast Asia, is to ensure that formal pronouncements and intent are implemented, 
and the entire environmental enforcement chain becomes effective.

3
 
11.  Over the past 20 years, SAARC countries have acknowledged the role of the judiciary in 
environmental  law  enforcement.  India’s  environmental  jurisprudence  is  characterized  by 
innovations  that  introduce  international  environmental  law  principles  into  decisions  and 
constitutional interpretations. Environmental jurisprudence in Bangladesh has been similarly 
progressive and environmental courts have been established in two districts along with an 
environmental appellate court.     
 
12.  In Pakistan, prior to the Environmental Protection Act, 1997, environmental enforcement 
depended on decisions of the higher judiciary through public interest litigation, which means that 
unless a case was brought before the judges, it was not considered a violation; moreover, in 
order to establish a violation, principles of natural justice were relied upon. The 1997 act 
enabled  the  designation  of  environmental  magistrates  and  mandated  the  creation  of 
environmental tribunals, which are now functioning in most of its provinces. Any violation of 
environmental principles is now considered a violation of law. The challenge in South Asia, like 
in Southeast Asia, remains to ensure that support of senior judges is institutionalized, and that 
the capacity of lower courts is strengthened.  
 
13.  Based on the offer of the chief justices of Indonesia and Pakistan, this TA will provide 
systematic  and  timely  support  tailored  to  the  needs  of  the  judiciary,  prosecutors,  and law 
enforcement officials in two pilot countries: Indonesia (through ASEAN) and Pakistan (through 
SAARC).  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of this initiative will be better prepared and adjudicated environmental cases 
in ASEAN and SAARC countries.  
 
15.  The  outcome  will  be  refined  environmental  law  prosecution,  adjudication,  and 
enforcement systems in the two pilot countries. This outcome will be achieved by ensuring that 
access  to  environmental  justice  is  increased  by  strengthening  environmental  compliance, 
adjudication, dispute resolution, and the enforcement chain. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  This TA will involve regional, subregional, and national activities.  Regionally, the TA will 
develop AJNE by fostering subregional work through two proposed groups within SAARC and 
ASEAN. Nationally, the TA will support needs-based activities in the pilot countries to ensure 
that the systems for access to justice are fortified and integrated. The TA will build on past work 
by ADB to boost capacity for environmental law and also capitalize on work conducted by 
development partners to reinforce environmental compliance and enforcement.   
 
17.  Output 1 – Regional and subregional: increased knowledge of adjudication and 
enforcement  of  environmental  law  through  a  judicial  network  and  sharing  of  good 
practices. This output will help ADB and its development partners establish and strengthen a 
judicial network for continual sharing of environmental cases, information, and best practices. 
Although there is an established network of Asian environment ministries (AECEN), a separate 
and specialized judges’ network is called for since the judiciary is a separate, co-equal branch of 
the government, bound by a more stringent code of conduct, i.e., neutrality and confidentiality

4  
that may not be understood by non-judges. Thus, in sharing information and experience, a 
specialized judges’ network, parallel to the ministers’ network (AECEN), is an ideal set-up to 
provide systematic and timely support tailored to the needs of the judiciary. Endorsement and 
ownership of AJNE, including a proposal for a rotating national chair supported by a small 
permanent secretariat, will be sought from regional judges. Activities under this output include (i) 
hosting the second Asian Judges’ Symposium in conjunction with ADB’s development partners, 
to  continue  sharing  best  practices  and  report  on  developments;  (ii)  establishing  an  AJNE 
website to offer training and other analytical material on building capacity of judges to decide 
environmental cases; and (iii) holding at least one subregional roundtable in each pilot country 
for  higher  courts,  subordinate  courts,  prosecutors  and  law  enforcement  officials,  attorneys 
general, and other legal professionals to boost capacity through knowledge sharing. 
 
18.  Output 2 – National: results from integrated environmental enforcement pilots in 
Indonesia and Pakistan disseminated. This output will help ADB and its partners provide 
systematic  and  timely  support  tailored  to  the  needs  of  the  judiciary,  prosecutors,  and law 
enforcement officials in the pilot countries.  Activities under this component will include: 
 
(i) Pakistan. The TA will support judicial capacity building in environmental adjudication 
by conducting a needs assessment in collaboration with the Supreme Court, federal 
and  provincial  judicial  academies,  and  environmental  tribunals.  Based  on  the 
assessment,  an  environmental  law  program  will  be  developed  or  broadened  and 
integrated in the judicial academies’ curriculum. In coordination with chief justices of 
the supreme court and provincial high courts, the TA will also look into the possibility of 
establishing  green  benches  (selected  teams  of  judges  with  experience  in 
environmental adjudication from within the existing judiciary to act as an environmental 
bench) for each of the four provinces. Once the green benches have been specified, 
they will be trained in environmental law and enforcement. The TA will also strengthen 
environmental libraries for the green benches.  
 
(ii) Indonesia. Good environmental governance requires that the three access rights—
access to information and justice, and public participation—embodied in Principle 10 of 
the Rio Declaration be made the pillars of decision- and policymaking in promoting 
environmental governance. Thus, this TA will support work for both the formal and 
informal justice systems to ensure that access rights are strengthened and enforced. 
The TA will help cement access to environmental justice by continuing to work with the 
judiciary on the environmental judicial certification program and by supporting the 
piloting  (possibly  in  two  areas,  Kalimantan  and  Makassar)  of  an  integrated 
enforcement  system  involving  MOE-I,  the  attorney  general,  and  law  enforcement 
agencies. The pilot integrated enforcement system will also build the capacity of civil 
society  to  raise  legal  rights  awareness  within  the  community  and  foster  public 
participation in environmental issues.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The  estimated  cost  of  the  TA  is  $1,020,000  equivalent,  of  which  ADB  will  finance  
$500,000  on  a  grant  basis  from  its  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF—IV)  and 
$500,000 from the Regional Cooperation Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and

5
Integration Financing Partnership Facility.4 The remaining $20,000 is expected to be financed in 
kind by the governments of the pilot countries. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency, through the Office of the General Counsel, which will 
work  closely  with  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department,  Southeast  Asia 
Department, and Central and West Asia Department, as necessary to ensure full coordination. 
The implementing agencies for activities in Pakistan will be the Pakistan branch of IUCN and for 
activities  in  Indonesia,  MOE-I.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  in  close  partnership  with  the 
supreme  courts,  high  courts,  environmental  tribunals,  and  national  prosecution  and  law 
enforcement  offices  in  the  pilot  countries.  ADB  will  also  continue  its  work  with  other 
development partners, such as AECEN, the Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in 
Commerce,  UNEP,  the  United  States  Environmental  Protection  Agency,  and  the  World 
Resources Institute.5    
 
21.  ADB will recruit 24 person-months of international consultant services for the overall 
management of the TA and 117 person-months of national consultants—two consultants for 
each pilot country, and one coordinator and one IT specialist for AJNE. The consultants will be 
contracted by ADB using the individual selection method in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The individual selection 
method is chosen because (i) it is considered to be more economical and efficient for the TA, 
(ii) it is very hard to find firms specializing in environmental law and enforcement in the pilot 
countries, and (iii) the experience and qualification of the consultants is a primary consideration 
in the selection. Procurement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time) and the procured items will be handed over to the pilot 
countries upon TA completion. Disbursement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
22.  Implementation progress will be monitored through (i) ADB's inception, interim, and final 
review  missions;  (ii)  workshops  and  seminars;  and  (iii)  draft  and  final  project  reports  and 
publications. The findings under the TA will be disseminated through workshops, seminars, and 
disclosure of the final reports on the websites of ADB and its development partners. The           
TA will be implemented over 3 years, from January 2011 to December 2013. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for  Building  Capacity  for  Environmental  Prosecution,  Adjudication,  Dispute  Resolution, 
Compliance, and Enforcement in Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Project Team Leader (international, 24 person-months) 
1.  Objective  and  purpose  of  the  assignment.  Because the technical assistance will 
support interventions at three levels—(i) regional: establishment of a judicial network on the 
environment;  (ii)  subregional:  conduct  of  roundtables  in  countries  of  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
(SAARC); and (iii) national: pilot activities in two countries—a project team leader is needed to 
implement, oversee, and coordinate the work at the different levels. 
 
2.  Scope of work. Under the supervision of the project officer, the consultant is expected 
to: 
(i)  establish the Asian Judges’ Network on the Environment (AJNE) by liaising 
and coordinating with the judiciaries from ASEAN and SAARC countries; 
(ii)  support the website consultant in establishing the AJNE website and portal, 
including the development of an information-sharing system;  
(iii)  provide inputs to the second Asian Judges’ Symposium;  
(iv)  provide inputs to the framework for the subregional roundtables, and liaise 
and coordinate with the host country and secretariat for the event; and 
(v)  support the project officer, implementing agencies, and national consultants in 
coordinating and designing, implementing and evaluating the pilot activities in 
the pilot countries.  
 
3.  Output  and  reporting  requirements.  All reports are expected to be in English, in 
accordance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) formatting requirements, and submitted in 
hard copy and compact disk (CD) formats: 
 
(i)  a draft 12-month work plan at the start of the consultancy period; 
(ii)  a project assessment report after the first year of project implementation; and 
(iii)  draft and final assessment reports at project end, including a sustainability 
plan for the AJNE. 
 
4.  Level of effort. The consultant is expected to provide needs-based, intermittent support 
over 24 months.  
 
5.  Qualification requirements. The consultant must have: 
 
(i)  at  least  12  years  of  experience  in  managing  environmental  law  projects, 
preferably in the Asian region or at least in a developing country; and 
(ii)  strong background on environmental access rights. 
 
B.  National Team Leader (Indonesia and Pakistan national, 24 person-months)  
6.  Objective and purpose of the assignment. The regional, subregional, and national 
activities of the project are expected to complement and contribute to the development of 
environmental justice in the pilot countries. Thus, a national team leader is needed in both 
Indonesia and Pakistan to organize and coordinate project activities, and ensure that they feed 
into the program and help widen access to environmental justice.

10   Appendix 3 
 
 
7.  Scope of work. The consultant will: 
 
(i)  prepare a needs assessment for the judiciary and enforcement agencies to 
support implementation of technical assistance activities;  
(ii)  in coordination with the project officer and project team leader, prepare an 
implementation plan for the selected project activities;  
(iii)  organize  and  coordinate  the  judges’  roundtable,  working  closely  with  the 
implementing agencies and the Supreme Court; and 
(iv)  organize, coordinate and liaise with all stakeholders in implementing project 
activities in the pilot country, including preparing a survey or research report 
to monitor and evaluate project activities. 
 
8.  Output  and  reporting  requirements.  All reports are expected to be in English, in 
accordance with ADB formatting requirements and submitted in hard copy and compact disk 
(CD) formats: 
 
(i)  12-month work plan at the start of the consultancy period; 
(ii)  midterm progress report on the implementation of project activities; and 
(iii)  a final report on the evaluation of project implementation. 
 
9.  Level of effort. The consultant is expected to provide needs-based, intermittent support 
over 24 months.  
 
10.  Qualification requirements. The consultant must have: 
 
(i)  at least 8–10 years of experience in environmental law and familiarity with the 
pilot country’s environmental legal framework and issues; and 
(ii)  strong background in managing and implementing environmental law projects 
in the pilot country. 
 
C.  National Project Coordinator (Indonesia and Pakistan national, 24 person-months) 
11.  Objective  and  purpose  of  the  assignment.  The  national  project  coordinator  is 
expected to support the national team leader in coordinating and implementing project activities. 
 
12.  Scope of work. The consultant, under the direction and supervision of the national team 
leader, will manage the organization and logistics of project activities and events, including the 
regional roundtable, and coordinate outputs and other deliverables for the project leader. The 
consultant will also provide research support on environmental law issues such as access rights, 
enforcement,  and  judicial  education  and  training;  and  assist  the  national  team  leader  in 
conducting surveys and preparing reports. 
 
13.  Output  and  reporting  requirements.  All reports are expected to be in English, in 
accordance with ADB formatting requirements, and submitted in hard copy and compact disk 
(CD) formats: 
 
(i)  baseline data as agreed on subject areas; and 
(ii)  monthly report on project activities and implementation, including statistics, to 
be incorporated in the national team leader’s reports.

Appendix 3  11 
 
14.  Level of effort. The consultant is expected to provide needs-based, intermittent support 
over 24 months.  
 
15.  Qualification requirements. At least 6–8 years of experience in environmental law, and 
familiarity with the pilot country’s environmental legal framework and issues.  
 
D.  Asian Judges’ Network Coordinator (national, 24 person-months) 
16.  Objective  and  purpose  of  the  assignment. A program coordinator is expected to 
support the project team leader in establishing the AJNE. 
 
17.  Scope of work. The consultant, under the direction and supervision of the project team 
leader, will support the organization and logistics of the AJNE, and coordinate outputs and other 
deliverables  for  the  project  leader.  The  consultant  will  coordinate  and  liaise  with  different 
judiciaries as well as the national team leader in getting and collating data for the website, and 
assist with the logistics of the regional roundtables. 
 
18.  Output and reporting requirements. A semi-annual report on project activities and 
implementation, including statistics, to be incorporated in the project team leader’s reports. All 
reports are expected to be in English, in accordance with ADB formatting requirements, and 
submitted in hard copy and CD formats. 
 
19.  Level of effort. The consultant is expected to provide 264 intermittent working days over 
24 months.  
 
20.  Qualification requirements. Familiarity with environmental law and relevant issues.  
 
E.   Information Technology Specialist (national, 9 person-months) 
 
21.  Object and purpose of the assignment. The consultant will be responsible for the 
development, establishment, and initial management of the AJNE website. 
 
22.  Scope of work. Based on the information needs of the network and using the specified 
local contents and available IT applications: (i) prepare a draft design of the website, written and 
visual, for the AJNE portal in English for the project officer’s approval; (ii) establish a working 
AJNE website; (iii) facilitate stakeholders’ access to the AJNE website; and (iv) help resolve any 
technical issues faced by the website during the implementation period of the project. 
 
23.  Output  and  reporting  requirements.  All reports are expected to be in English, in 
accordance with ADB formatting requirements, and submitted in hard copy and CD formats: 
 
(i)  inception report on possible ways and systems to be established to collect 
data that would be fed into the AJNE website; 
(ii)  monthly, semi-annual and annual statistics on website hits, downloads, and 
other data that will be requested for compilation; 
(iii)  final report at project end that includes statistics and recommendations on 
institutionalization and sustainability of the website. 
 
24.  Level of effort. The consultant is expected to provide 9 person-months of intermittent 
service over 24 months.

12   Appendix 3 
 
 
25.  Qualification  requirements.  At  least  10  years  of  experience  in  web  design,  and 
familiarity with establishing electronic regional working networks and editing electronic materials.
